text: Micah prophesied during the reigns of which kings of Judah?
verseText: The word of the LORD that came to Micah of Moresheth in the days of Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah...

text: Micah's prophecy concerned which two capital cities?
verseText: ...which he saw concerning Samaria and Jerusalem.

text: Like Amos, Micah strongly condemned what sins?
options: Social injustice, corruption among leaders and prophets, idolatry
verseText: (Examples: Woe to those who devise wickedness... they covet fields and seize them; Is it not for you to know justice?— you who hate the good and love the evil; its heads give judgment for a bribe; its priests teach for a price; its prophets practice divination for money)

text: In Micah 4, what famous prophecy is made about the mountain of the LORD's house and the nations?
options: Nations will flow to it, and they will beat swords into plowshares
Only Israel will be allowed there
It will be moved to Babylon
verseText: It shall come to pass in the latter days that the mountain of the house of the LORD shall be established as the highest of the mountains... and nations shall flow to it... they shall beat their swords into plowshares, and their spears into pruning hooks; nation shall not lift up sword against nation, neither shall they learn war anymore.

text: Micah 5:2 prophesies that the future ruler of Israel will come from which small town?
verseText: But you, O Bethlehem Ephrathah, who are too little to be among the clans of Judah, from you shall come forth for me one who is to be ruler in Israel, whose coming forth is from of old, from ancient days.

text: This prophecy from Micah 5:2 is famously quoted in the New Testament in relation to whose birth?
verseText: (The chief priests and scribes quote Micah 5:2 to Herod when asked where the Christ was to be born)

text: In Micah 6, God brings a legal case against Israel. What does He ask them in verse 3?
options: 'O my people, what have I done to you? How have I wearied you?'
verseText: “O my people, what have I done to you? How have I wearied you? Answer me!

text: What three things does the LORD require of humanity, according to Micah 6:8?
options: Offer thousands of rams, ten thousand rivers of oil, give your firstborn
Build temples, offer sacrifices, pray daily
Do justice, love kindness (mercy), walk humbly with your God
Keep the Sabbath, pay tithes, attend festivals
verseText: He has told you, O man, what is good; and what does the LORD require of you but to do justice, and to love kindness, and to walk humbly with your God?

text: Despite the pervasive wickedness described in Micah 7, where does the prophet resolve to look?
options: To the LORD; wait for the God of his salvation
To the past glories of Israel
verseText: But as for me, I will look to the LORD; I will wait for the God of my salvation; my God will hear me.

text: How does Micah end, expressing confidence in God's character?
options: With a curse on Israel's enemies
With praise for God's pardoning iniquity and showing steadfast love and faithfulness
verseText: Who is a God like you, pardoning iniquity and passing over transgression for the remnant of his inheritance? He does not retain his anger forever, because he delights in steadfast love... You will show faithfulness to Jacob and steadfast love to Abraham...

text: Micah was a contemporary of which major prophet known for his ministry in Jerusalem?
verseText: (Both Micah and Isaiah prophesied during the reigns of Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah).

text: In Micah 1:3-4, how is the LORD's coming in judgment described?
options: Treading on the high places, mountains melting like wax, valleys splitting
verseText: For behold, the LORD is coming out of his place, and will come down and tread upon the high places of the earth. And the mountains will melt under him, and the valleys will split open, like wax before the fire, like waters poured down a steep place.

text: What is identified as the primary transgression of Jacob and sin of the house of Israel in Micah 1:5?
verseText: All this is for the transgression of Jacob and for the sins of the house of Israel. What is the transgression of Jacob? Is it not Samaria? And what is the high place of Judah? Is it not Jerusalem?

text: What fate does Micah prophesy for Samaria in Micah 1:6?
options: It will become the capital of the world
It will become a heap of ruins in the open country, a place for planting vineyards
verseText: Therefore I will make Samaria a heap in the open country, a place for planting vineyards, and I will pour down her stones into the valley and uncover her foundations.

text: Micah 1:10-16 contains a series of puns on town names in Judah, describing the coming judgment. What general feeling does this section convey?
options: Widespread mourning, shame, and disaster spreading towards Jerusalem
verseText: (Examples: 'Tell it not in Gath'; weeping in Beth-le-aphrah - 'house of dust'; the inhabitants of Shaphir - 'pleasantness' - in nakedness and shame; disaster has come down from the LORD to the gate of Jerusalem).

text: What specific sin is condemned in Micah 2:1-2?
options: Coveting fields/houses and seizing them through oppression
verseText: Woe to those who devise wickedness and work evil on their beds! When the morning dawns, they perform it, because it is in the power of their hand. They covet fields and seize them, and houses, and take them away; they oppress a man and his house, a man and his inheritance.

text: What do the false prophets tell Micah (and true prophets) not to do in Micah 2:6?
options: 'Do not prophesy about judgment; disgrace will not overtake us'
verseText: “Do not preach”—thus they preach— “one should not preach of such things; disgrace will not overtake us.”

text: What kind of message were the people and false prophets willing to accept, according to Micah 2:11?
options: Someone prophesying of wine and strong drink
verseText: If a man should go about and utter wind and lies, saying, “I will preach to you of wine and strong drink,” he would be the preacher for this people!

text: Despite judgment, what promise is given to the 'remnant of Israel' in Micah 2:12?
options: They will be assimilated by other nations
God will assemble them like sheep in a fold
verseText: I will surely assemble all of you, O Jacob; I will gather the remnant of Israel; I will set them together like sheep in a fold, like a flock in its pasture, a noisy multitude of men.

text: Who does Micah accuse of 'hating the good and loving the evil' and 'eating the flesh' of God's people in Micah 3:1-3?
options: The rulers (heads) of Jacob and rulers of the house of Israel
verseText: And I said: Hear, you heads of Jacob and rulers of the house of Israel! Is it not for you to know justice?— you who hate the good and love the evil, who tear the skin from off my people and their flesh from off their bones, who eat the flesh of my people...

text: What will happen when these unjust rulers cry out to the LORD (Micah 3:4)?
options: He will hide His face from them
He will send Micah to help them
verseText: Then they will cry to the LORD, but he will not answer them; he will hide his face from them at that time, because they have made their deeds evil.

text: What motivates the prophets Micah condemns in Micah 3:5?
options: Whether or not people feed them ('put something into their mouths')
verseText: Thus says the LORD concerning the prophets who lead my people astray, who cry “Peace” when they have something to eat, but declare war against him who puts nothing into their mouths.

text: What specific judgments are pronounced on the corrupt leaders, priests, and prophets in Micah 3:11-12?
options: Zion will be plowed as a field, Jerusalem a heap of ruins, the temple mount a wooded height
They will be exiled to Egypt
verseText: Its heads give judgment for a bribe; its priests teach for a price; its prophets practice divination for money; yet they lean on the LORD and say, “Is not the LORD in the midst of us? No disaster shall come upon us.” Therefore because of you Zion shall be plowed as a field; Jerusalem shall become a heap of ruins, and the mountain of the house a wooded height.

text: The vision in Micah 4:1-5 is also found almost identically in which other prophetic book?
verseText: (Isaiah 2:2-4 contains a very similar prophecy about the mountain of the Lord's house and nations seeking instruction).

text: In the era of peace described in Micah 4:4, what will every man do?
options: Sit under his vine and fig tree with none to make him afraid
verseText: but they shall sit every man under his vine and under his fig tree, and no one shall make them afraid, for the mouth of the LORD of hosts has spoken.

text: Micah 4:6-7 promises that God will gather whom and make them a strong nation?
options: The lame, the outcasts, those afflicted
verseText: In that day, declares the LORD, I will assemble the lame and gather those who have been driven away and those whom I have afflicted; and the lame I will make the remnant, and those who were cast off, a strong nation; and the LORD will reign over them in Mount Zion from this time forth and forevermore.

text: Where does Micah 4:10 say the people of Zion will go before being rescued?
verseText: Writhe and groan, O daughter of Zion, like a woman in labor, for now you shall go out from the city and dwell in the open country; you shall go to Babylon. There you shall be rescued; there the LORD will redeem you from the hand of your enemies.

text: How is the remnant of Jacob described among the nations in Micah 5:7?
options: Like dew from the LORD, like showers on the grass
verseText: Then the remnant of Jacob shall be in the midst of many peoples like dew from the LORD, like showers on the grass, which delay not for a man nor wait for the children of man.

text: How else is the remnant of Jacob described among the nations in Micah 5:8?
options: Like a lion among the beasts of the forest
verseText: And the remnant of Jacob shall be among the nations, in the midst of many peoples, like a lion among the beasts of the forest, like a young lion among the flocks of sheep, which, when it goes through, treads down and tears in pieces, and there is none to deliver.

text: What things will God cut off from Israel in the day of restoration, purging them from false reliances (Micah 5:10-14)?
options: Horses, chariots, strongholds, sorceries, carved images, pillars, Asherim
verseText: And in that day, declares the LORD, I will cut off your horses from among you and destroy your chariots; and I will cut off the cities of your land and throw down all your strongholds; and I will cut off sorceries from your hand... And I will root out your carved images and your pillars from among you... and I will root out your Asherim...

text: In God's lawsuit (Micah 6), who are called to be witnesses?
options: The mountains and hills, the foundations of the earth
verseText: Arise, plead your case before the mountains, and let the hills hear your voice. Hear, you mountains, the indictment of the LORD, and you enduring foundations of the earth, for the LORD has an indictment against his people, and he will contend with Israel.

text: What specific acts of God's redemption does He remind Israel of in Micah 6:4-5?
options: Bringing them out of Egypt, redeeming them from slavery, sending Moses, Aaron, Miriam; Balaam/Balak incident
verseText: For I brought you up from the land of Egypt and redeemed you from the house of slavery, and I sent before you Moses, Aaron, and Miriam. O my people, remember what Balak king of Moab devised, and what Balaam the son of Beor answered him... that you may know the righteous acts of the LORD.”

text: What inadequate offerings does the questioner propose in Micah 6:6-7 before the famous answer in verse 8?
options: Burnt offerings, calves, thousands of rams, ten thousand rivers of oil, firstborn son
verseText: “With what shall I come before the LORD...? Shall I come before him with burnt offerings, with calves a year old? Will the LORD be pleased with thousands of rams, with ten thousands of rivers of oil? Shall I give my firstborn for my transgression, the fruit of my body for the sin of my soul?”

text: What specific dishonest practices are condemned in Micah 6:10-11?
options: Wicked treasures, short ephah (measure), wicked scales, deceitful weights
verseText: Can I forget the treasures of wickedness in the house of the wicked, and the scant measure that is accursed? Shall I acquit the man with wicked scales and with a bag of deceitful weights?

text: Whose wicked statutes and practices were the people following, leading to judgment (Micah 6:16)?
verseText: For you have kept the statutes of Omri, and all the works of the house of Ahab; and you have walked in their counsels, that I may make you a desolation...

text: How does Micah describe the state of society in Micah 7:2-4?
options: The godly have perished, none upright; all lie in wait for blood; hands are skilled at doing evil; prince, judge, great man conspire
verseText: The godly has perished from the earth, and there is no one upright among mankind; they all lie in wait for blood, and each hunts the other with a net. Their hands are on what is evil, to do it well; the prince and the judge ask for a bribe, and the great man utters the evil desire of his soul; thus they weave it together. The best of them is like a brier, the most upright of them a thorn hedge.

text: Micah 7:5-6 warns against trusting whom in such corrupt times?
options: Neighbors, friends, spouses, family members (son/father, daughter/mother)
verseText: Put no trust in a neighbor; have no confidence in a friend; guard the doors of your mouth from her who lies in your arms; for the son treats the father with contempt, the daughter rises up against her mother... a man's enemies are the men of his own house.

text: What confidence does Micah express even if he falls or sits in darkness (Micah 7:8)?
options: The LORD will be his light and he will rise
He will find his own way
verseText: Rejoice not over me, O my enemy; when I fall, I shall rise; when I sit in darkness, the LORD will be a light to me.

text: What reason does Micah give for bearing the LORD's indignation (Micah 7:9)?
options: Because he has sinned against God
verseText: I will bear the indignation of the LORD because I have sinned against him, until he pleads my cause and executes judgment for me. He will bring me out to the light; I shall look upon his vindication.

text: What will happen to the enemy who taunted, 'Where is the LORD your God?' (Micah 7:10)?
options: They will join Israel in worship
They will see God's vindication and be covered with shame, trampled down
verseText: Then my enemy will see, and shame will cover her who said to me, “Where is the LORD your God?” My eyes will look upon her; now she will be trampled down like the mire of the streets.

text: Micah 7:14 contains a prayer asking God to do what for His people?
options: Shepherd them with His staff, let them feed in Bashan and Gilead
verseText: Shepherd your people with your staff, the flock of your inheritance, who dwell alone in a forest in the midst of a garden land; let them graze in Bashan and Gilead as in the days of old.

text: God's future deliverance will be like the wonders shown during what past event (Micah 7:15)?
options: The coming out of the land of Egypt
verseText: As in the days when you came out of the land of Egypt, I will show them marvelous things.

text: How will the nations react when they see God's mighty deeds of restoration (Micah 7:16-17)?
options: They will be ashamed, silent, deaf, lick the dust like serpents, and tremble before God
verseText: The nations shall see and be ashamed of all their might; they shall lay their hands on their mouths; their ears shall be deaf; they shall lick the dust like a serpent, like the crawling things of the earth; they shall come trembling out of their strongholds; they shall turn in dread to the LORD our God, and they shall be afraid of you.

text: What characteristic of God does Micah emphasize in the closing verses (Micah 7:18)?
options: His uniqueness in pardoning iniquity and delighting in steadfast love (mercy)
verseText: Who is a God like you, pardoning iniquity and passing over transgression for the remnant of his inheritance? He does not retain his anger forever, because he delights in steadfast love.

text: What will God do with Israel's iniquities according to Micah 7:19?
options: Tread them underfoot and cast them into the depths of the sea
verseText: He will again have compassion on us; he will tread our iniquities underfoot. You will cast all our sins into the depths of the sea.

text: The final verse (Micah 7:20) affirms God's faithfulness to the covenant promises made to which patriarchs?
verseText: You will show faithfulness to Jacob and steadfast love to Abraham, as you have sworn to our fathers from the days of old.
